title: Drivers causing blinding incidents on UK roads with illegal headlights

title_detail.value: Drivers causing blinding incidents on UK roads with illegal headlights

summary: Motoring campaigners say the trend to replace worn-out halogen bulbs with LED 'upgrades' may be a key factor in the epidemic of blinding incidents on Britain's roads.

summary_detail.value: Motoring campaigners say the trend to replace worn-out halogen bulbs with LED 'upgrades' may be a key factor in the epidemic of blinding incidents on Britain's roads.

author: Nick Constable
generated_summary: Research suggests that a growing number of drivers in Britain are illegally installing super-bright LED headlights in vehicles not designed for them, leading to an increase in blinding incidents on the roads. The RAC has highlighted the safety risks, noting that one in 20 drivers have reported near-collisions due to headlight glare. Campaigners from Lightaware warn that replacing halogen bulbs with LEDs can cause poor beam alignment and glare, as halogen housings are not compatible with LED bulbs. Despite being marketed as 'halogen replacements,' these LED bulbs are only legal for use on private land. Many drivers may unknowingly break the law until their vehicle fails its MoT. The government has commissioned further research into this issue, as 91% of surveyed drivers reported being dazzled by headlights, with 74% experiencing it regularly.

title: Who is Patrick Stewart? Everything you need to know about Rangers' new CEO

title_detail.value: Who is Patrick Stewart? Everything you need to know about Rangers' new CEO

summary: The former interim CEO at Manchester United is set to land the role at Rangers.

summary_detail.value: The former interim CEO at Manchester United is set to land the role at Rangers.

author: Joshua Barrie
generated_summary: Patrick Stewart is set to become the new CEO of Rangers FC, succeeding James Bisgrove, who left the club in May. Stewart, who has a background as a solicitor, worked with UEFA's marketing agency for the Champions League and held various roles at Manchester United, including interim CEO earlier this year. His appointment comes as Rangers also prepare to name Malcolm Offord as the new Chairman, ending a period of executive instability at the club. Stewart's experience includes serving as General Counsel at Manchester United, where he established the club's in-house legal and regulatory function. His new role at Rangers will involve overseeing the club's executive operations and potentially appointing a new sporting director.

title: Former Manchester United CEO set to land Rangers chief executive role

title_detail.value: Former Manchester United CEO set to land Rangers chief executive role

summary: Rangers are expected to name former Manchester United chief Patrick Stewart as their new chief executive officer.

summary_detail.value: Rangers are expected to name former Manchester United chief Patrick Stewart as their new chief executive officer.

author: Christopher Jack
generated_summary: Patrick Stewart, former Manchester United executive, is set to become the new CEO of Rangers FC, succeeding James Bisgrove, who left for a position in Saudi Arabia. Stewart, who spent 14 years at Manchester United, including a stint as interim CEO, will lead Rangers on a day-to-day basis. This appointment comes as part of a broader leadership restructuring at the club, with Malcolm Offord expected to be named the new chairman. Former director John Gilligan and investor George Letham have been managing the club's operations and search for new leadership. This move marks a significant change in the club's management as they aim to stabilize and strengthen their executive team.

title: Survey reveals number of EV chargers in Fife as network continues to grow

title_detail.value: Survey reveals number of EV chargers in Fife as network continues to grow

author: Allan Crow
generated_summary: A recent survey reveals that the number of public electric vehicle (EV) chargers in Fife has increased by 36% over the past year, rising from 166 to 226 chargers as of July. Despite this growth, the RAC has raised concerns about uneven distribution of chargers across the UK, with some areas having significantly more chargers per capita than others. In Fife, there are 61 public chargers per 100,000 people, including 45 rapid chargers. The UK government aims to install 300,000 public EV chargers by 2030, requiring approximately 3,600 new installations monthly. The Department for Transport emphasizes its commitment to accelerating the rollout to enhance accessibility and encourage the transition to zero-emission vehicles.

title: AA warns drivers to do quick 5 step routine to de-frost car

title_detail.value: AA warns drivers to do quick 5 step routine to de-frost car

summary: Drivers are being warned to not drive off until they have completed these five steps

summary_detail.value: Drivers are being warned to not drive off until they have completed these five steps

author: Sophie Buchan
generated_summary: The AA has issued a warning to drivers against using online hacks for defrosting car windscreens, which could potentially damage vehicles. Instead, they recommend a five-step routine: checking that wipers are not frozen, starting the engine with warm air directed at the windscreen, removing all snow from the car, using a scraper and de-icer on the outside, and ensuring all glass is clear before driving. The AA emphasizes that using hot or cold water on windscreens can cause cracking or further freezing, leading to costly repairs.

title: Electric cars less likely to breakdown than petrol and diesel models, new report finds

title_detail.value: Electric cars less likely to breakdown than petrol and diesel models, new report finds

summary: AA recorded only five or six EV breakdowns per year due to running out of battery

summary_detail.value: AA recorded only five or six EV breakdowns per year due to running out of battery

author: Hemma Visavadia
generated_summary: A recent report highlights that electric vehicles (EVs) in the UK are less prone to breakdowns compared to petrol and diesel models, with battery-related issues accounting for only 1.85% of EV breakdowns. This marks a significant improvement from previous years, attributed to advancements in battery technology, increased charger availability, and better driver education. The AA reports handling around 8,000 vehicle breakdowns daily, with only a small fraction involving EVs running out of charge. The trend aligns with similar patterns in Norway, suggesting that range anxiety is diminishing. The AA anticipates EV reliability will soon match that of conventional vehicles, though some drivers remain hesitant about transitioning to EVs.

author: Jalopnik Staff
generated_summary: This week's Car Culture Roundup by Jalopnik highlights several notable automotive stories. Key topics include the unveiling of the 2026 Hyundai Ioniq 9, a spacious and aerodynamic three-row electric SUV, which debuted ahead of the Los Angeles Auto Show. The roundup also covers the end of MotorTrend's popular car show "Roadkill" after 13 seasons, and Jake Paul's dramatic entrance in a custom '90s truck for his fight against Mike Tyson. Additionally, discussions on electric vehicle sounds and the impact of potential tariffs on Mexican imports by Trump are featured. The roundup provides a diverse look at current automotive trends and news.

title: WATCH NOW: Footage reveals drivers endangering British bin workers

title_detail.value: WATCH NOW: Footage reveals drivers endangering British bin workers

author: Hemma Visavadia
generated_summary: The article highlights a significant road safety issue in Cornwall, where bin workers are endangered by reckless driving. During Road Safety Awareness Week, Cornwall Council released footage showing vehicles mounting pavements and narrowly avoiding waste collection crews, violating Highway Code rule 145. Over the past two years, CCTV has captured numerous incidents, prompting safety concerns as these crews service up to 2,500 properties daily. Biffa, the collection service operator, reports that workers also face verbal abuse. Offenders risk fines, court summons, or mandatory education courses for such dangerous driving, which is classified by the Metropolitan Police as a serious offence. Councillor Carol Mould and Roads Policing Temporary Chief Inspector Dean Drury emphasize the need for patience and consideration on the roads to prevent potential injuries or fatalities.

title: Oxford Bus Company staff raise funds for special school

title_detail.value: Oxford Bus Company staff raise funds for special school

summary: IT WAS their job to keep Oxford buses running on the roads, but they still made time to support worthy causes

summary_detail.value: IT WAS their job to keep Oxford buses running on the roads, but they still made time to support worthy causes

author: Andrew Ffrench
generated_summary: In 1985, staff at the Oxford Bus Company, then known as City of Oxford Motor Services, raised over £3,000 for charitable causes, including purchasing a computer for the Mabel Prichard School for handicapped children. They also allocated funds to support the John Radcliffe Hospital’s special care baby unit and financed holidays for children at the Park Hospital in Headington. The funds were raised through raffles, charity auctions, and a London to Brighton cycle race. Their efforts earned them recognition as one of the top fundraising teams in Britain, securing an additional £250 prize for their charity fund. The Oxford Bus Company continues to serve Oxfordshire, now operating from a new base in Cowley.

title: Number of electric vehicle chargers in Dudley fell by a tenth last year

title_detail.value: Number of electric vehicle chargers in Dudley fell by a tenth last year

summary: The number of public electric vehicle chargers drivers had access to in Dudley fell by a tenth last year, new figures show.

summary_detail.value: The number of public electric vehicle chargers drivers had access to in Dudley fell by a tenth last year, new figures show.

author: Stourbridge News Staff
generated_summary: The number of public electric vehicle (EV) chargers in Dudley decreased by 10% last year, dropping from 198 to 179, according to new figures from the Department for Transport. This decline raises concerns about inconsistent EV charger availability across the UK, with the RAC highlighting disparities in charger distribution. While the government aims to install 300,000 public chargers by 2030, Dudley currently has 55 chargers per 100,000 people, which is below the national average. The RAC emphasizes the need for prioritizing regions with poor charger access to ensure equitable EV infrastructure development. Despite these challenges, the UK is on track to meet its 2030 target, with 65,000 chargers installed nationally as of July, marking a 47% increase from the previous year.

title: The next 12 Norwich streets to get electric car chargers

title_detail.value: The next 12 Norwich streets to get electric car chargers

summary: Work to install electric vehicle charging points on another dozen Norwich streets will begin next week.

summary_detail.value: Work to install electric vehicle charging points on another dozen Norwich streets will begin next week.

author: Dan Grimmer
generated_summary: Norfolk County Council is set to install electric vehicle charging points on 12 additional streets in Norwich, beginning next week. The project, part of a 2021 strategy to promote electric vehicle use, involves installing 22 new charge points by February next year. This initiative follows a deal with Blink Charging UK and aims to support a greener future by providing accessible charging infrastructure. So far, 24 charge points have been installed, with nearly 200 vehicles charged in the first four months of operation. The council emphasizes the importance of public chargers for residents without private driveways, as evidenced by a public consultation.

title: Norfolk firm launches new department to fulfil international orders

title_detail.value: Norfolk firm launches new department to fulfil international orders

summary: Prior Power Solutions, in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to fulfil a growing number of…

summary_detail.value: Prior Power Solutions, in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to fulfil a growing number of…

author: Adam Barker
generated_summary: Prior Power Solutions, based in Great Yarmouth, has launched a new welding and fabrication department to meet increasing international demand. This expansion allows the company to offer in-house fabrication for their products, enhancing quality control, reducing lead times, and providing cost-effective solutions. The department has already completed ten skid frames for the offshore industry, adhering to DNV 2.7-1 standards. Established in 1980 as Prior Diesel Ltd and rebranded in 2020, the firm is part of the Suretank Group, serving the offshore oil and gas sector. The new department is a result of significant investment in staff training, equipment, and infrastructure, with projects already extending to countries like Angola.

title: Changes driven by Musk biggest threat to China under Trump 2.0, adviser warns

title_detail.value: Changes driven by Musk biggest threat to China under Trump 2.0, adviser warns

summary: Greatest pressure to ‘come from changes within the US’, Zheng Yongnian says, urging China to expand opening up as a countermeasure.

summary_detail.value: Greatest pressure to ‘come from changes within the US’, Zheng Yongnian says, urging China to expand opening up as a countermeasure.

author: South China Morning Post
generated_summary: China's primary concern during a potential second term for Donald Trump as U.S. president is the possibility of significant U.S. government changes influenced by tech mogul Elon Musk, according to Zheng Yongnian, a prominent Chinese political scientist. Zheng advises that China should counter this by expanding its unilateral opening-up measures, particularly towards the U.S., to gain leverage in the ongoing US-China rivalry. He predicts that while Trump's policies might lead to short-term economic and trade disruptions for China, geopolitical tensions could lessen. Zheng also warns that Trump's "America First" strategy, particularly through tariffs, could severely harm bilateral relations and the global trade system.
